summary: Manage CCPA opt-out of personal information sale
detailed_description: Manage CCPA opt-out of personal information sale. This policy provides comprehensive controls and enforcement mechanisms aligned with industry standards and best practices. It enables organizations to maintain compliance, reduce security risks, and automate policy enforcement.

use_cases.title: Google: CCPA for California Consumer Data
use_cases.description: Tech giant implementing California consumer privacy rights
use_cases.scenario: Google (40M California users) implements CCPA: Consumer rights portal (access, deletion, opt-out of sale), 'Do Not Sell My Personal Information' link, service provider contracts (cannot sell data), annual privacy disclosures. California AG compliance: Strong consumer rights implementation, transparent data practices.

use_cases.title: Target: CCPA for Retail Customer Data
use_cases.description: Retailer managing California consumer information under CCPA
use_cases.scenario: Target (10M California customers) provides CCPA rights: 15-day access requests (personal info disclosure), 45-day deletion requests (verified deletion across systems), opt-out of sale honored (no sharing with third parties for money), no discriminatory pricing for opt-out. Results: 20K CCPA requests annually, 98% within deadlines, zero AG enforcement actions.

use_cases.title: Salesforce: CCPA as Service Provider
use_cases.description: Cloud platform ensuring CCPA compliance for business customers
use_cases.scenario: Salesforce (data processor for 150K businesses with California consumers) implements CCPA: Service provider agreements (cannot sell customer data), data deletion upon customer request, sub-processor restrictions. CCPA compliance: Contractual obligations clear, data flow mapping for customer CCPA requests, strong processor compliance.

conditions.name: user.authenticated
conditions.plain_english: Runtime evaluation of 'user.authenticated' to make access control decisions based on current request context.
conditions.how_to_fetch:
Configure Control Core to fetch 'user.authenticated':
1. In Control Core Admin UI, go to Settings > Attribute Sources
2. Click 'Add Attribute Source' and select your identity/data provider
3. Map 'user.authenticated' to the corresponding field in your source system
4. Configure refresh interval (e.g., cache for 5 minutes, fetch on each request for sensitive data)
5. Test the mapping with sample users to verify correct values are retrieved
6. Enable the attribute for use in policies
